none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 21, 1886
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 21, 1886
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 22 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

OFFICE OF
G. W. & G. L. LOVELL.

FOREIGN AND INLAND
Bills of Exchange.

BANKERS.

BONDS AND MORTGAGES
Bought & Sold.

Monticello, Iowa. July 21 1886

Louis L. McInnis
Forest Miss.

My Dear Friend & Bro.: - Upon returning from
Neb. I found your letter and was glad to hear from
you indeed. You say you are coming North
probably during August - can you not
arrange so as to pass in our vicinity ? or
are you going more East than North. When do
you attend the Cond [?] I have not yet heard when
it is called but suppose it will be sometime
in August. The ticket war is over and I was
just lucky enough to get home before the rates
went up again - made a difference of about 75 Dols
in my favor. Am taking the Cashrs place here
during his absence. business dull - as it is
everywhere. Hear from Whitlock & Smith occasionally
they seem to be enjoying the trip & visit hugely.
Yes Mallory is one of us now & I am glad of it
for his sake - guess he has a splendid wife
Did he send you the Tenn. paper containing

**Transcription Process Deep Dive** Okay, here's how I'm thinking through this transcription. First, I need to understand the task. I'm acting as a professional transcriptionist, and the goal is to reproduce the text from an image, accurately and in the right format. This means paying attention to detail: going top-to-bottom, left-to-right, preserving the original spelling, breaks, and handling any difficult handwriting. I have to use specific Markdown or HTML tags which are very limited (`a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, `sup`), and I'll use a Markdown table for any data. I am *only* outputting the transcribed text, nothing more. Now, let's break down the image. There's an elaborate header, which I'll analyze carefully. "OFFICE OF" is at the top. The main name looks like "G.W. & G.L. LOVELL." I need to double-check those initials; the "G"s look ornate, but I'm confident in the "L"s. It's "LOVELL" for sure. The word "BANKERS." is inside a decorative border. The left side says "FOREIGN AND INLAND / Bills of Exchange." The right side says "BONDS AND MORTGAGES / Bought & Sold." Next, the handwritten section. It's "Monticello, Iowa. July 21 1886" as the date and location. The addressee is "Louis L. McInnis / Forest Miss." Then the salutation: "My Dear Friend & Bro.:". I'm making a mental note that "Bro." likely means "Brother," perhaps a fraternal order or close friendship. Moving into the body, the first lines say, "Upon returning from / Neb. I found your letter and was glad to hear from / you indeed." Then, "You say you are coming North / probably during August - can you not / arrange so as to pass in our vicinity? or / are you going more East than North." Then there's the phrase I'm focusing on: "When do / you attend the Cond? [Conv? Comd?]" I think this word is `Cond` or `Conv`. The context implies a convention or something similar, likely in August. I will examine it carefully. It does have a looping ending. I need to make sure I get it right based on the shape of the letters. It could be "Conv" or "Cond". The letter ends abruptly. There's more text: "The ticket war is over and I was / just lucky enough to get home before the rates / went up again - made a difference of about 75 Dols / in my favor." Then, "Am taking the Cash'rs place here / during his absence. business dull - as it is / everywhere. Hear from Whitlock & Smith occasionally / they seem to be enjoying the trip & visit hugely. Yes Mallory is one of us now & I am glad of it / for his sake - guess he has a splendid wife Did he send you the Tenn. paper containing" I'm now drafting the transcription, either mentally or on a scratchpad. The header is going to be: "OFFICE OF", "G. W. & G. L. LOVELL.", "BANKERS.", "FOREIGN AND INLAND / Bills of Exchange.", and "BONDS AND MORTGAGES / Bought & Sold." The date line is "Monticello, Iowa. July 21 1886". The address is "Louis L. McInnis / Forest Miss." For the body, I am going to write: "My Dear Friend & Bro.: - Upon returning from Neb. I found your letter and was glad to hear from you indeed. You say you are coming North probably during August - can you not arrange so as to pass in our vicinity ? or are you going more East than North. When do you attend the Cond [?]". I think it might be "Conv". I'll consider that option. "I have not yet heard when it is called but suppose it will be sometime in August. The ticket war is over and I was just lucky enough to get home before the rates went up again - made a difference of about 75 Dols in my favor. Am taking the Cashrs place here during his absence. business dull - as it is everywhere. Hear from Whitlock & Smith occasionally they seem to be enjoying the trip & visit hugely. Yes Mallory is one of us now & I am glad of it for his sake - guess he has a splendid wife Did he send you the Tenn. paper containing" Next, it's formatting time. I need to use `

` tags for paragraphs. The small, or span tags for the header elements to

the acct of the wedding? quite nice –
Mrs Curtis & myself often speak of Mrs.
Molf & little Lilla and wish we could see
you all. Here comes a fellow with a plugged
50c piece – [crossed out: Lots of queer] customers
around a bank – Some of them come in
& look around furtively as if they were
ashamed to be seen here – These generally
want to borrow money – Others come in
with head up & mouth open [crossed out: these] they
want you to give them the exch. on a
Draft – or something of the kind –

I see Bringhurst has appointed
"Prof" W B Phillpot asst in Eng. well
I suppose they could do a great deal
worse – don't you? The drouth must
be assuming enormous proportions in Tex.
I see by papers cattle are dying by the
M's. Aren't you glad you are not
there this weather? Write us & keep us in-
formed about yourselves –

With best wishes & kindest regards to all
I am as ever
Geo. W. Curtis

1886

**Transcription Process: A Detailed Log** Okay, here's how I approached this transcription, breaking down each step to ensure accuracy and adherence to the specific instructions. My primary goal, as always, is to provide a faithful rendering of the source text, adhering meticulously to the provided guidelines and maintaining the integrity of the original material. First, I examined the request itself. I'm acting as a professional transcriptionist, tasked with transforming a handwritten document into digital text. The instructions are clear: read top-to-bottom, preserve spelling and punctuation as is, interpret handwriting using [?] for uncertainty and [illegible] for unreadable content, maintain the original layout (paragraph structure), and handle any marginalia appropriately. Importantly, I can only use a specific set of HTML tags: `a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, and `sup`. My output should be *only* the transcribed text, no extraneous commentary or interpretation beyond what's specified. Next, I analyzed the image itself. I'm looking at a handwritten letter, likely written in ink on aged paper. The handwriting is cursive, somewhat hurried but generally legible. There's a crease that goes right through the middle, which I will need to accommodate. The text appears to be a continuation of a letter, starting mid-sentence, so I need to piece together the beginning with the given context. Now, for the actual line-by-line transcription. I went through each line carefully, checking the letterforms, the context, and ensuring proper interpretation. I tried to render the text as accurately as possible. * **Line 1**: The first line required particular scrutiny. I had to decipher the word between "the" and "of." The initial analysis brought up possibilities like "acc," "acct," or even "act." The letter formation hinted toward 'a', then tall stroke, then 'c', with some looping on the crossbar, suggesting 'acct' (account) as the most probable interpretation. I considered "details" but, given the context of a letter, account made more sense. I'll note that. * **Line 2**: This was pretty straightforward, accurately transcribing Mrs. Curtis and the personal pronoun and names, and proper nouns. * **Line 3**: The name "Molf" needed careful examination. The initial thought was "Wolf" or "Moll", but it was important to consider the consistent formation of letter "M" in the word "Mrs". The "W" in the word "Write" (near the end of the letter) is very distinct, and the "M" is rounded. The letter at the beginning of "Molf" has a rounded top loop, so based on the visual evidence, it's "Molf". I recorded it as such, but kept "Moll" as a distant possibility. * **Line 4-5**: These lines had a "plugged 50c" which was clear. Line 5 included a strikethrough - something I cannot represent literally. The phrase "Lots of queer" was crossed out and I cannot use `` or ``. I had to analyze what remained on the line, and ultimately how the sentence would be structured. Context, with the word "customers," shows that "queer" was an adjective before that noun. My interpretation, per the instructions, is to include the crossed out text, but explicitly indicate its state through the brackets with "crossed out" indication. * **Line 6-12**: Fairly straightforward lines. Correct transcription and proper interpretation, especially the "exch" (exchange) abbreviation. * **Line 13-14**: The name "Bringhurst" was clear, the "Prof" in quotes. The name Phillpot had to be verified. * **Line 15-24**: The final paragraphs were straightforward with the main difficulty on an "M's" on line 19. It looked like a capital M followed by an apostrophe + s, which, given the context, suggested thousands. I took note of "drouth" as correct archaic spelling. Regarding the HTML formatting, I followed the explicit instructions. I structured the transcription into paragraphs based on the visual layout of the original text, using `

` tags. Line breaks within the paragraphs were rendered with `
`. My only constraint was the inability to use the `` or `` tags. This meant that I had to include the crossed-out text to be accurate but must do so while following the rules. I opted to describe the crossed-out text by using brackets: `[crossed out: text]`. I ensured consistent capitalization, and included the date at the bottom using ``. Throughout the process, the emphasis has been on accurate interpretation,
